awd_titl_txt: CREST Center for the Integrated Study of Coastal E
awd_abstract_narration:
Center for the Integrated Study of Coastal Ecosystem Processes and Dynamics in the Mid-Atlantic Region

With National Science Foundation support, the University of Maryland Eastern Shore will continue operations of the Center for the Integrated Study of Coastal Ecosystem Processes and Dynamics in the Mid-Atlantic Region. This Center brings together a team of scientists with expertise in geochemistry, phytoplankton and zooplankton ecology, fish ecology, environmental microbiology, biogeochemistry, and physical oceanography to conduct a collaborative study of the effects of climate variability on trophic interactions and food web dynamics, exchange of materials between Maryland Coastal Bays and the coastal ocean, and dynamics of heterotrophic bacteria.  

Coastal lagoons such as Maryland Coastal Bays are very productive ecosystems that serve as nurseries for many economically and ecologically important species of finfish and shellfish.  Coastal lagoons have restricted water exchanges with the coastal ocean. As a result, they are not well flushed, and are vulnerable to nutrient enrichment and pollutant accumulation. The Center for the Integrated Study of Coastal Ecosystem Processes and Dynamics in the Mid-Atlantic Region emphasis is on understanding the dynamics and processes within the Maryland coastal lagoon and estuarine ecosystems.

A hydrodynamic model will be developed and used to evaluate the magnitude of material transport between the Maryland Coastal Bays and the coastal ocean through the northern and southern inlets. A particle tracking model will be used to assess the dispersal and retention of gelatinous zooplankton and ichthyoplankton in the Maryland Coastal Bays. Additionally, information on the dynamics of heterotrophic bacteria including Vibrio species will be examined, and the possible role of Vibrio as a stressor leading to co-infection by other microbes in crabs will be investigated. Abiotic and biotic variables will be used to develop models for predicting the occurrence of Vibrio species.

The Center for the Integrated Study of Coastal Ecosystem Processes and Dynamics in the Mid-Atlantic Region will positively impact the number of minority students that obtain degrees in marine and environmental sciences. The Center will integrate research and education by recruiting and educating high school students, middle school and high school teachers, and undergraduate and graduate students, particularly members of underrepresented groups.
org_div_long_name: Div. of Equity for Excellence in STEM

pgm_ele.pgm_ele_name: Centers for Rsch Excell in S&T

por.por_cntn:
From 2016 to 2022, research at the NSF CREST-CISCEP resulted in 31 peer-reviewed publications, 5 articles in revision or submitted to journals for publication, and 8 manuscripts in preparation. Sixty (60) presentations were made at major scientific meetings, and 9 theses and dissertations were completed.  Research results from the Center have enhanced knowledge of coastal lagoon ecosystems, particularly Maryland Coastal Bays (MCBs). Highlights of some of the Center's research outcomes are presented below.

The concentrations of heavy metals in MCBs sediments have decreased compared with metal levels recorded 20 years ago (Ahemedaltayb 2022). However, recent data suggest that the bays are polluted with endocrine disrupting chemicals based on assessments of estrogenic activities of samples from the bays (Elfadul et al. 2021).  Our research has also contributed new information on the spatial and seasonal occurrence of harmful algal blooms (Oseji et al. 2019, Wolny et al. 2022). 

Using stable isotope ratios of nitrogen (δ15N) and carbon (δ13C), we characterized the sources of organic carbon in suspended particulate matter (SPOM) in the MCBs (Edje et al. 2020), and the response of copepods to variations in the δ15N and δ13C contents of SPOM (Edje and Chigbu 2021).  Furthermore, the trophic ecology of selected fish species were studied based on gut contents, stable isotopes and fatty acids analyses (Richardson 2021).  

Studies on benthic macroinvertebrates resulted in the description of the abundance and diversity relative to biotic and abiotic factors (Krieg et al. 2022).  Additionally, new species were described including, Carinacuma umesi, a new genus and species of bodotriid cumacean (Morales-Nunez and Chigbu, 2021). A new locality record of the Asian isopod Ianiropsis cf. serricaudis was also reported (Morales-Nunez and Chigbu, 2018). Rubalcava et al. (2022) constructed a mass-balanced model of trophic interactions among 22 key functional producer and consumer groups in the MCBs using Ecopath software to examine the structure and energy flows, and quantify resiliency in the system in comparison with nearby estuaries. 

The distribution of sand shrimp (Crangon septemspinosa) was evaluated and found to be influenced by temperature (Chigbu et al. 2019). We also examined the factors influencing the recruitment and distribution of brown shrimp (Farfantepenaeus aztecus) and observed that its abundance was inversely correlated with freshwater discharge, but positively correlated with the North Atlantic Oscillation winter index (Rubalcava and Chigbu 2022). To provide guidance on the best locations to consider in future oyster population enhancement, Farmer (2021) assessed patterns in oyster larvae settlement and found the highest abundance near MCBs inlets.

Understanding water circulation in the MCBs is important for quantifying the transport of materials such as nutrients and plankton into and out of the bays. Kang et al. (2017) used a three-dimensional unstructured-grid based hydrodynamic model validated using observed data such as salinity, current velocity and water level to simulate the exchange of materials between the MCBs and the coastal ocean. To study water dynamics in the MCBs during Hurricane events, Mao and Xia (2018) used observational data to calibrate and validate a wave-current coupled model during Hurricane Irene that occurred in 2011.  In addition to simulating the maximum total water surface elevation under hurricane conditions, they observed that tidal currents dominated inlet circulation, whereas ocean swells dominated wave dynamics. Furthermore, Kang and Xia (2020) investigated the influence of Hurricane Sandy on water exchanges in the MCBs, and described how flux patterns via the two inlets changed with wind speed and direction, and increasing/decreasing high water levels from the coastal ocean. Finally, Fitzenreiter et al. (2022) used data from surface drifters deployed at various tidal phases and wind conditions and analyzed the relative influence of winds and tides on estuarine and coastal circulation through the Ocean City and Chincoteague inlets.

Our researchers have also documented seasonal patterns of occurrence of human pathogenic bacteria, Vibrio vulnificus and Vibrio parahaemolyticus in MCBs water and blue crabs, and are developing Vibrio spp. predictive models (Smalls and Parveen 2022).  They have also determined the antimicrobial and genetic profiles of the Vibrio species isolated from the bays (DaSilva et al. 2021). Moreover, our team investigated the microbial community diversity of whole crab and seawater from MCBs using 16S rRNA sequencing (Smalls and Parveen 2022). 

The Center has made significant contributions to human resource development in STEM, particularly in marine sciences. Ninety-three (93) individuals were trained: 57 undergraduates, 19 graduate students, 3 post-doctoral research associates, and 14 middle and high school teachers. Of these numbers, 71% of graduate students, and 76% of undergraduates in the programs belonged to underrepresented minority groups. One of the Center graduate students received the 2022 Maryland Sea Grant State Science Policy Fellowship. Three of the recent Ph.D. recipients from the Center held post-doctoral fellowships, including an NSF CREST post-doctoral fellowship, and five of the graduates work at federal or state agencies as a fisheries biologist, oceanographer, or environmental scientist.


Last Modified: 04/27/2023
Modified by: Paulinus Chigbu
